Alas!  my poor native domain,</br>Now vanish'd for ever from me;</br>Condemn'd in these deserts to reign,</br>I ne'er shall look back upon thee.
The clock from the neighbouring tow'r</br>Was wont to respond to its round,</br>Was wont to re-echo the hour,</br>And deal its fleet moments by sound.
But here rears no temple its head,</br>No moss crowns the mouldering wall,</br>No pray'r is rehearsed o'er the dead,</br>Nor decency throws on the pall.
No knell flings its summons on high,</br>Or wafts to a purer abode,</br>Or, when Omai is summon'd to die,</br>Commends his remains to his God!
Had honesty drawn back this hand,</br>Or piety beam'd on this breast,</br>I ne'er had been torn from my land,</br>And William might still have been blest.
My infant had still climb'd my knee,</br>And innocence dawn'd on its smile;</br>Him fortune forbids me to see,</br>Condemn'd to a tenantless soil.
If death bears its breath to repose</br>In the flattering dawn of its day,</br>Its eyes I'm forbidden to close,</br>And shed my regret on its clay.
How happy the man who can find</br>Contentment a native delight!</br>'Tis the sanative spring of the mind,</br>'Tis a fruit which no tempest can blight.
He ne'er will despond on a spot</br>So rugged, so barren as mine;</br>He ne'er will re-echo his lot</br>To the savage, the rock, and the pine;
For they who partook in my fate</br>Have forsaken my presence, and fled;</br>Reflexion ne'er wept at their state,</br>Or conscience in penitence bled.
Farewell, ye gay pleasures, which gave</br>Your shadowy joys to my youth!</br>With sorrow I sink to the grave,</br>So flattery differs from truth.
With me let my country condole,</br>Let my family sigh a farewell,</br>Till (if mercy may visit my soul)</br>In happier climes we may dwell.
There Peace shall display her white wand,</br>Compassion shall blot out the tear,</br>And somewhat employ my weak hand</br>More bless'd than hath call'd for it here.</br>
